utterances: So are we going to get to point, though, where we have like, OK, here's Khafeel for you and Sadia for you?
I hope we don't reach this thing.
Kelly McEvers, NPR News, Baghdad.
The University of Connecticut women's basketball team made history last night in Hartford.
They won their 89th consecutive game with a 93-62 rout of Florida State.
The team, which hasn't lost a game since April 2008, surpassed a record set back in the 1970s by the UCLA men's team, a team coached by the legendary John Wooden.
Last night's victory was typical of UConn's incredible streak.
As NPR's Mike Pesca reports, it was a blowout, and against a very good opponent.
Eighty-nine, it's not such a special number.
It's the first prime number made up of two composite numbers, so that's kind of cool.
Doesn't necessarily justify this sort of noise.
(Soundbite of cheering)
Of course, 89 was also the number of games in a row that the University of Connecticut's women's basketball team was going for last night.

In a sold out arena in Hartford against the Florida State team that didn't ask to have history step on its face, the UConn women were about to do something that opposing coach Sue Semrau would later characterize as...
It's still impossible to me, you know, that it's happened.
Maybe Coach Semrau was influenced by the fact that Connecticut's Maya Moore had 26 points at halftime, whereas the entire FSU team had 27.
Moore would go on to score 41 points, the highest total by any player during the streak.
By the second half it was clear that the Huskies would not be relenting.
Their fans, like Connecticut sophomore Rachel Weiss, began to talk not just about this win or this season, but the team's place in history.
All UConn, and for that matter all basketball fans should understand the immensity of this streak and the accomplishment they've come up with.
A couple of days ago, UConn's coach, Geno Auriemma, opined that the only reason people cared so much about 89 was that it was a women's team beating a men's record.
Randy Edsel, who coaches UConn football, champions of the Big East, was at the game, ready to speak up for Auriemma and his team.
It doesn't matter if it's men's basketball or women's basketball - you know, give them their due.
They deserve every recognition that they get.
It's hard to win a couple games in a row, let alone 89 in a row.
In Auriemma's post-game press conference, during which time he took a call from the father of two female basketball players...
Mr.
President, I really appreciate that.
Auriemma said that anyone belittling 89 wins in a row must not have accomplished anything extraordinary.
Those that have done significant things, they know when you do something really significant, that's hard to do, they appreciate it.
I just ask for everybody to admire what these kids do and how they do it and how hard it is to do it.
Overall, the tone of Auriemma and his team was reflective.
They neither exulted nor exhaled.
They weren't saying we did it as much as they avowed we're doing it.
There was a subtle but telling choice made after the game as the team posed at center court.
A fan tossed the players a UCLA jersey, name on the back Wooden, the number 88 crossed out.
The jersey wasn't held up to the cameras.
In fact, it was quickly tucked away by an assistant coach so no one would see it.
UConn didn't beat UCLA, and they didn't win a title.
As the team posed for the horde of cameras, they weren't holding onto a trophy, they were holding onto each other.
(Soundbite of cheering)
...eighty-nine consecutive victories.
Mike Pesca NPR News, Hartford, Connecticut.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Robert Siegel.
When the mortgage crisis exploded here in the U.S., it brought down the housing market and the rest of the economy with it.
The recession that followed cut to the core of the American dream.
For generations, owning a home has been essential to the kind of life most Americans aspire to.
But the crash in home prices, millions of foreclosures and tighter lending standards have left many Americans unable or too nervous to buy a house.
Here's NPR's Chris Arnold with the latest in our series American Dreams.
Since the housing crash, there have been all kinds of headlines about how Americans are rethinking homeownership.
There was Time magazine's cover, quote, ""Why owning a home may no longer make economic sense."" Pundits claim that renting would be the new owning, that a major shift was afoot.
This was on CNN.
(SOUNDBITE OF NEWS REPORT)
I prefer to rent.
I like the flexibility that comes along with renting.
The face of a new generation of renters, and perhaps the future of home dwelling in general.
So, is renting becoming the future of home-dwelling in general?
In a word, no. Five years after the crash, the desire to own a home is actually very much alive and well.
There you go.
There you go, Lilah.
At the kitchen table in the house her parents just bought, 11-month-old Lilah Medeiros is eating mashed up vegetables and making elephant sounds.
E is for elephant.
E is for elephant.
There you go.
OK.
They're not exactly like real elephant sounds, but they're very impressive.
Good job, Lilah.
You ready for another bite?
Oh, no.
Lilah's parents are Jared and Emily Medeiros.
They're in their mid-30s.
They both work at a museum, and they just bought their first house.
It's here in Sharon, Massachusetts, and it's a suburb outside of Boston.
And it turns out that this is something that most Americans still want to do.
A poll of likely voters out last week from the non-partisan Woodrow Wilson Center found that 84 percent of people said that homeownership is just as or more important than it was five years ago.
We got a nice front yard, backyard, side yard, two side yards.
It's big.
You know, like, he does some, like, woodwork stuff.
He can, like, do his projects on the weekends, and I can do some gardening and...
That Wilson Center poll also found that 90 percent of people still think that homeownership is a part of the American dream.
I do feel like we kind of are living the dream.
We've said it a couple times since we bought the place, really worth it with the dream.
We kind of are.
Like, this is what you always picture is, like, having the space to do this stuff.
And now we do.
It's not just the suburbs.
Other young families are buying homes or condos in neighborhoods in the city.
And the desire to own a home, and own your own piece of land, has deep roots in the American psyche.
Bob Shiller is a housing economist at Yale.
Well, you know, the American dream, that is a term that became popular in the 1930s.
But I kind of associate it with the suburban movement that developed after World War II.
And to me, homeownership at that time represented a kind of a community spirit.
You know, we have neighbors, we like our neighbors.
We're active in the community.
And Shiller says it's been an American tradition to encourage homeownership, or farm ownership before that, for a very long time.
